title: Quadratics Deep Dive
description: Go beyond basic factoring to master completing the square, the quadratic formula, and complex number solutions, unlocking the full power of quadratic analysis.
goals: Convert fluently between standard, factored, and vertex forms of quadratics
Solve quadratics using ALL methods: factoring, square root, completing the square, quadratic formula
Use the discriminant to predict the number and type of solutions
Graph parabolas using transformations from the parent function y = x²
Perform operations with complex numbers and solve equations with complex solutions
instructionalStrategy: Students saw quadratics in Algebra 1. The Algebra 2 approach goes DEEPER: every form reveals different information (standard → y-intercept, factored → x-intercepts, vertex → min/max), and the 'which method?' decision is the real skill.

Completing the square is THE key technique of this unit—it derives the quadratic formula, converts to vertex form, and reappears in conic sections (Unit 8). If students can complete the square fluently, everything else follows.
The discriminant (b²-4ac) is a diagnostic tool: positive → 2 real solutions, zero → 1 repeated, negative → 2 complex. Teach students to CHECK the discriminant BEFORE choosing a solving method.
Complex numbers feel alien at first. Ground them in necessity: 'x² + 1 = 0 has no REAL solutions, so we invent a number system where it does.' The powers of i cycle: i, -1, -i, 1, repeat.

For 'which method?' problems: factoring is fastest when it works; square root method for (x+a)² = b; completing the square always works and gives vertex form; quadratic formula is the universal fallback.

scaffold.title: Concept: Quadratic Forms Converting
scaffold.initialPrompt: Given y = 2(x - 3)² - 8, what form is this? What is the vertex? Now convert it to standard form and then try to factor it.
scaffold.content:
**Three Forms of a Quadratic — Each Reveals Different Information:**

| Form | Equation | Reveals |
|------|----------|--------|
| **Standard** | y = ax² + bx + c | y-intercept (c), direction (a), axis of symmetry (-b/2a) |
| **Factored** | y = a(x - r₁)(x - r₂) | x-intercepts (r₁ and r₂), direction (a) |
| **Vertex** | y = a(x - h)² + k | Vertex (h, k), direction (a), min/max value (k) |

**Converting Between Forms:**
• Standard → Factored: factor the expression
• Standard → Vertex: complete the square
• Factored → Standard: FOIL and distribute a
• Vertex → Standard: expand (x-h)², distribute a, combine
• Any form → Standard is always possible; Standard → Factored requires factorable zeros

The sign of **a** determines:
• a > 0: parabola opens UP (minimum at vertex)
• a < 0: parabola opens DOWN (maximum at vertex)

scaffold.title: I-Do: Quadratic Forms Converting — Worked Examples
scaffold.initialPrompt: Notice that the vertex (3, -8) is exactly halfway between the x-intercepts 1 and 5 (average = 3). Is this always true? Why?

examples.problem: Convert y = 2x² - 12x + 10 to vertex form and factored form.
examples.solution:
**To Vertex Form (complete the square):**
y = 2x² - 12x + 10
y = 2(x² - 6x) + 10          — factor out a from x-terms
y = 2(x² - 6x + 9 - 9) + 10   — add and subtract (b/2)² = 9 inside
y = 2(x² - 6x + 9) - 18 + 10  — distribute the -9 out (multiply by 2)
y = **2(x - 3)² - 8**

Vertex: (3, -8). Opens up. Minimum value is -8.

**To Factored Form:**
0 = 2x² - 12x + 10 = 2(x² - 6x + 5) = 2(x - 1)(x - 5)
y = **2(x - 1)(x - 5)**

x-intercepts: (1, 0) and (5, 0).

**All three forms describe the SAME parabola:**
• Standard: y = 2x² - 12x + 10 → y-intercept is 10
• Vertex: y = 2(x - 3)² - 8 → vertex at (3, -8)
• Factored: y = 2(x - 1)(x - 5) → zeros at 1 and 5

scaffold.title: Concept: Discriminant Analysis
scaffold.initialPrompt: What is i⁷³? (Hint: divide 73 by 4 and look at the remainder.)
scaffold.content:
**Complex Numbers:**

The imaginary unit **i** is defined so that **i² = -1** (equivalently, i = √(-1)).

**Standard form:** a + bi, where a is the real part and b is the imaginary part.

**Operations:**
• Add/Subtract: combine real parts and imaginary parts separately
  (3 + 2i) + (1 - 5i) = 4 - 3i
• Multiply: use FOIL, remembering i² = -1
  (2 + 3i)(4 - i) = 8 - 2i + 12i - 3i² = 8 + 10i + 3 = 11 + 10i
• Divide: multiply by the **conjugate** of the denominator
  (3 + i)/(2 - i) × (2 + i)/(2 + i) = (6 + 3i + 2i + i²)/(4 + 1) = (5 + 5i)/5 = 1 + i

**Powers of i cycle every 4:**
i¹ = i, i² = -1, i³ = -i, i⁴ = 1, i⁵ = i, ...

**Complex Conjugate:** The conjugate of a + bi is a - bi. Their product is always REAL: (a+bi)(a-bi) = a² + b².

scaffold.title: I-Do: Discriminant Analysis — Worked Examples
scaffold.initialPrompt: Could we have used completing the square instead? Try it: x² + 4x + 13 = 0 → (x+2)² = ? What happens when the right side is negative?

examples.solution:
**Check discriminant first:**
D = b² - 4ac = 16 - 52 = -36
D < 0 → two complex conjugate solutions.

**Quadratic formula:**
x = (-4 ± √(-36))/2
x = (-4 ± 6i)/2
x = **-2 ± 3i**

**Verify:** Plug in x = -2 + 3i:
(-2+3i)² + 4(-2+3i) + 13
= (4 - 12i + 9i²) + (-8 + 12i) + 13
= (4 - 12i - 9) + (-8 + 12i) + 13
= -5 - 12i - 8 + 12i + 13
= 0 ✓

**Key pattern:** Complex solutions ALWAYS come in conjugate pairs. If -2 + 3i is a solution, then -2 - 3i must also be a solution.

problems.question: Use the discriminant to match: (a) x²+6x+9=0, (b) x²+2x+5=0, (c) x²-5x+2=0. Which has 1 repeated real, 2 complex, or 2 distinct real solutions?
problems.answer: (a) D=0 → 1 repeated real. (b) D=-16 → 2 complex. (c) D=17 → 2 distinct real.
